What is your overall assessment of this course?
The course was well organized to facilitate student learning.

Comments_Questions: What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course?
What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved?
Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain.
Comments_List: The course helped me to understand the dynamics of storytelling and identify my strengths and weaknesses in writing.
I learned how to pitch a screenplay. The collaborate setting helped me develop critical readings and constructive criticism skills.

The course is very immersive and well-rounded in terms of aiding students in identifying where they could improve and where their work is good. However, student feedback could be more directed as often time, students don't really know what sort of feedback to give their peers.

One of the strengths of this course is the open nature of the discussions over everyone's work. Everyone is encouraged to give their honest feedback which can lead to the best discussions and is very helpful as a writer.

The small class size was one of the biggest strengths of the class because it allowed us to really engage in each others writing and tailor the speed of the class to our needs. I can't define any major weaknesses with this course.
If a student is interested in pursuing film, I would highly recommend this course.
Professor Lapadula is definitely more honest with students in his senior seminar. It can be frustrating but it's a great opportunity to get real feedback on your work if you're passionate about it.
I would recommend this course to another student. Learning the way to write a screenplay is helpful for any career in the film industry. It exposes students to a different style of writing.

Absolutely, I would recommend this course to a student who is serious about developing screenwriting skills. This class helps you think critically about storytelling through your own writing, and through the work of your peers. It's non competitive, but you still get the challenge of working with students who are equally invested in improving their writing skills
